text: my name is mark kaye i'm a professor of
pediatrics and genetics i'm a dennis
ferry family professor
and i'm a vice chair
associate chair for research in the
department of pediatrics for my phd i
studied drosophila
developmental genetics and that's where
i got interested in in genetic diseases
thinking that and when i go back to
medical school i should do something
that's a little more applicable to
medicine i have to say that when i
started my
graduate career i actually had a strong
interest in metabolism and
it was i guess
when i started looking at possible
research projects i got very interested
in
some of the new genetic ideas and some
of the ideas about
how
a single egg could differentiate into a
whole organism and that's really when i
got interested in more developmental
genetics these discoveries that you make
and knowing that you've found something
out about nature
that nobody else has known and making a
contribution to our understanding of
nature that really nobody else has known
or
developing or participating in the
development of a new treatment that will
be useful
for treating patients who have serious
diseases i mean those two things really
keep me going
